text:
They’re preparing the weapons in Eddie’s trailer when he notices it. Steve’s borrowing one of his t-shirts from the Hellfire Club from Eddie’s junior year. It’s already a bit small on Eddie, and it pulls tight now across Steve’s chest and stomach. And as they prepare for the impending battle, Eddie can’t even focus on the fact that there’s an impending battle . Mostly because Steve should not look good in a remnant of the worst year of Eddie’s life.

But also kind of because the way Steve sticks his tongue through his teeth just a bit every time the fabric hits his stomach a certain way. His wounds should be healing by now: it’s been two days since the upside down. Something about the way he reacts, though, to the shift of soft, well-worn fabric worries Eddie to no end.

So when Nancy suggests someone stay with Eddie while they go get dinner, he requests Steve.

“He’s hurt,” Eddie says.

“I’m fine.”

Jesus, Harrington. “And, I, uh, actually wanted some advice anyway.” He glances at Robin, because isn’t that what straight boys do . She’s watching Nancy, thank god.

Steve’s not: he’s staring straight at Eddie, like he’s trying to decode him. God, Eddie hopes he doesn’t get too far in that process.

Finally, Nancy lets up. And Eddie’s a bit relieved, because if she dedicated any more brain power to her ex, her brain might explode. Not that Vecna isn’t trying to do that already, but come on, Nance, he wants to scream. It was Robin who figured out your favorite song; not your ex. Eddie wonders if Vecna tormented Nancy about being queer while she was gone, or if she hasn’t addressed it yet. She should get on that, with how Robin watches her.

When they’re gone, Steve finally breaks the silence. “Look man, if you’re gonna ask about Robin, quit while you’re ahead. You’re really not her… um… type.”

Oh, so Steve knows. Maybe that makes things a little bit easier, then.

Or maybe Eddie just wants Steve to call him a fucking freak like everyone else. Maybe the inevitable rejection would hurt less.

“She’s not mine,” Eddie says, and he hopes to God Steve figures it out. From the useless look on his face, it isn’t clicking. So he moves on. “I just said that so you’d stay. Because, look, you’re clearly in a lot of pain right now. And I know you wanna play brave for everyone else, but trust me, I am the last person who wants that right now.”

Steve frowns. “I’m fine.”

“You aren’t.”

“I’m…” Steve stops, and exhales. He looks at his feet. “Yeah. No. I think it might be infected.”

Eddie’s lived in a trailer park most of his life, and if he learned one thing, it’s how to pull together back-alley cures for every ailment. Back when he lived two doors down with his parents, he used to help her mom take care of the kids on the block when they got hurt, or sick. Back then, he thought he’d be a doctor one day.

Now, he reflects briefly on his life while he digs through his uncle's liquor cabinet for a specific cheap vodka in a specific plastic bottle.

“Take your shirt off, and get on my bed,” Eddie calls. He wishes to god that came in another context.

And that’s the reason why, when he’s on his feet, and back in the room, his jaw almost drops. Because Steve isn’t sitting on his bed — he’s laying shirtless, on his back, with his head propped up on his arm. His muscles are tense, and he’s a bit sweaty.

He has a fever, Eddie realizes. And his attention snaps away from sex-god Steve Harrington and focuses in on the wounds at his side.

They’re a nasty shade of yellow and red, surrounded by every shade of green and blue and purple. They’re infected for sure, and Eddie isn’t even sure where to start.

“This is gonna hurt.” That sounds like as good a place as any.

He moves to Steve’s side, the one by the edge of his bed, so he doesn’t have to climb onto the bed with him just yet. He gets down on his knees, and as he uncaps the bottle, Steve asks, “Are you sure you know what you’re doing?”

Eddie glances up at him. “I’ve done this before, promise.” Yet another line Eddie would do anything to say on his knees to Steve in another very specific context.

“You sure?” And Eddie can hear it now, hear how terrified Steve is.

So, he does what his mom always did, when kids were scared: he tells a story. “My mom was a nurse. When I was growing up, well, a lot of families around here can't afford hospitals, or prescription medicine. On her days off, she did what she could with what we had to help out around here. So growing up, I did this a lot. Do you know how many kids don’t realize you have to wash the scraps on your knees?” Eddie suddenly pours the alcohol onto Steve’s wound. Steve screams, and tenses. He claws at Eddie with one hand, writhing from the intense burn. And Eddie rolls just out of the way, expertly capping the bottle before anything spills. Because Eddie has done this. A lot.

After a moment, Steve leans back on the bed and moans, “Holy fuck.” He looks like a wreck on Eddie’s bed, and Eddie literally has to look away – it’s a lot to handle without just imploding .

“Did that hurt?” Eddie asks, trying to mask the fact that he cannot breathe. Steve throws something at Eddie—Eddie’s only stuffed animal, a teddy bear—in response.

“Never again, Munson.”

Eddie finally manages his composure, and glances up. “We still have one more round of this, Harrington.”

“Oh, Jesus. I’m gonna need some of that, then.”

“You don’t want this shit. It’s, like, half Everclear, half the cheapest shit they sell.”

“Yeah? Trust me, after that, I do.”

Eddie hesitates, then says, “I’ll drink to that.”

Steve pats the bed next to him weakly. “Let’s get drunk, Eds.”

Eds? They’d circle back to that later. Eddie slowly circles around the bed, crawling up next to Steve but, like, in a chill bro way .

He hands the bottle off to Steve, who doesn’t even hesitate before tossing back quite a bit of the liquor. Eddie’s almost in awe. He lets Steve hold the bottle a moment longer, before taking it himself.

And in a flash, he dumps just enough on Steve’s other wound. Steve tries to punch Eddie this time, but Eddie just pushes him down into the bed. His hand fans out across Steve’s bare, shaggy chest for only a moment too long. Eddie decides it’s the pain that’s making Steve’s heart beat so fast.

“What the fuck Munson?” Steve won’t look Eddie in the eyes, just averting his glare lower.

“I’ll drink to that,” Eddie mumbles. He rolls back onto the bed, and tosses back some of the vodka himself. Unlike Steve, he coughs, loudly, and lurches forward. “Fuck, that’s fucking disgusting.”

“You get used to it,” Steve says, still wincing. Eddie offers him more, and he gladly accepts it.

A little while later, Eddie feels properly smashed. Maybe it’s the liquor on an empty stomach, or the boy lying next to him in the full size bed, but his body feels fake. Like it might betray him.

“What happened to your mom?” Steve asks quietly, his voice heavy with liquor and exhaustion and a little bit of sweetness Eddie hasn’t heard before.

“Huh?”

“I mean, what happened to her?”

“Oh.” Perhaps it wasn’t his body that would betray him, but his words. “Well…” He tries to think up the words. It was supposed to be a routine blood transfusion. It was supposed to just be anemia.

It was supposed to be her son who got it first, because he was the freak.

“She died,” Eddie says. Because everyone knows she died. Because clearly that’s not the answer Steve wants.

“How?”

And now Eddie folds. “She had it .”

It , the reason he never goes home with random guys from the crowds at shows. It , the word whispered in the hallways around Hawkins, attached to insult after homophobic insult. It , the disease that never should’ve been Eddie’s alone to deal with, before the media and the politicians and the small-minded people in his hometown got ahold of it.

Eddie waits for Steve to respond.

“Oh.” He just says. And then he adds, “I’m really sorry. Is that why you…”

“I what?” Eddie says it too quickly. Maybe he was wrong about Steve. Maybe he doesn’t know about Robin after all. Maybe he’s an ass like the rest of them.

“You stopped being Hawkins’ freaky genius kid?”

And now it’s Eddie’s turn to say, “Oh.” Because how would he have known Steve remembered that, once upon a time, Eddie was going places. Eddie barely does anymore.

“That was you, right? I remember being jealous of you, when they moved you straight from our seventh grade class to high school. I couldn’t wait to run with all the older kids, and you just… Did.”

“Yeah, well, it’s hard to graduate when your mom’s dying of… dying. Or when your dad disowns you. Or when you’re accused of murder.”

“Your dad disowned you?”

Eddie reaches out, and takes the bottle back from Steve. He takes a swig; Steve was right, he is getting used to it. And now, it’s now or never. Eddie doesn’t know if he should say what he’s about to, but he does.

“Yeah, well… My dad found out I was gay. I found out he was religious.” Steve doesn’t say anything, and Eddie doesn’t have it in him to look at him. He takes another draw of vodka, and continues on. “My uncle didn’t give a shit. His sister died because people were too busy hating on gay guys to focus on what mattered, so he took me in. Everyone at school already called me a freak, so nothing my dad said changed that. But there’s something about being told to pack your bags because you had a crush on Andy Felps—“

“Andy Felps?“ Steve says slowly. Eddie gulps.

“Yeah, Andy Felps.”

Steve bubbles for a moment, stuttering over a set of syllables that Eddie can barely make out. Finally, he manages, “But he’s so… I’m so much cooler than him.”

Eddie doesn’t even know how to respond at first, so he says the only drunk thing that pops into his mind. “Are you jealous, Harrington?”

“Yes.” Eddie immediately looks at Steve, and his intense proximity gives him the perfect vantage point from which to watch Steve’s eyes widen. “I mean, no! I mean… I guess I just think you should’ve had a crush on me and not… Andy Felps.”

And for once, Eddie isn’t convinced that Steve’s straight. In fact, the panic on his face is so much closer to the kind Eddie experienced back when he did like Andy.

“Well, I didn’t think you were a good dude until about two days ago.” Eddie’s still watching him, studying the flutter of his eyelashes, the casual way his head turns. Noting the intensity in Steve’s eyes as they lock with Eddie’s.

“And now?”

“And now you’re lying in my bed listening to me spill my deepest, darkest secrets,” Eddie finishes. Steve grins drunkenly.

He blinks, once, and then looks back to the ceiling. Eddie doesn’t think he’s imagining that Steve shifts a bit closer.

“We should, um, bandage you up.” Eddie gulps, overwhelmed by the sensation of Steve’s body heat. “But the right way, this time. Not with your ex’s t-shirt, or whatever.”

“Yeah, yeah. We… yeah.”

“Um. Just stay here, and I’ll grab the stuff from out front.” Pouring honey on Steve Harrington’s body would absolutely be too much to handle normally. Just to make it extra fun, Eddie grabs his handcuffs from the wall on the way back in.

“So you don’t hit me this time,” Eddie says, as he tosses them to Steve. Steve looks sufficiently nervous now.

“What’re you doing this time?” He asks, but Eddie watches as he dutifully puts on the handcuffs. Good boy , Eddie thinks. And then he blushes and looks away.

“Honey does a really good job of dressing wounds,” Eddie whispers, as he places one knee down on the thin layer of mattress between Steve and his side. “I’m gonna go ahead and kind of cover your cuts in the them, before I get you all wrapped up, okay?”

Steve watches Eddie’s every move as he fills the deep, messy cuts with honey, pooling on as much as he can of the thick golden syrup. Then, he shifts his knee between Steve’s legs. Steve gulps, but still he watches Eddie’s face. Maybe he’s waiting for Eddie to betray himself here. Eddie slowly slides the bandages under Steve’s back, catching some of the drizzled honey before it hits the mess of sheets beneath them. Eddie begins wrapping them around Steve’s toned, smooth torso, trying hard to not hyperfixate on the way Steve flexes when Eddie’s calloused fingers brush against his skin. And then he’s done, and still perched with half his body between Steve’s legs.

The front door opens, and, shockingly, Steve stays put until Nancy calls to them from the kitchen, proclaiming burgers and fries. Eddie shoves whatever shirt he can grab off the floor (a Sex Pistols shirt that Eddie cut the sleeves off of) in Steve’s direction, and heads into the kitchen. On the way down the hall, he swaps their medicinal vodka for a different, much tastier bottle of cheap vodka.

“Did you get the slushies?” Eddie asks. Nancy points to the counter next to her, as she and Robin dole out burgers (and a grilled cheese for Max).

“Where’s Steve?” Robin asks. She gives Eddie a quick head-nod in Nancy’s direction as he goes to put a little vodka in each slushy. A warning, Eddie thinks. He quickly dumps what he can in, and caps the bottle.

“Bedroom. We bandaged him up again.” Then, Eddie hip-bumps Nancy. “Your shirt wasn’t totally doing it, Princess.” She laughs, thank God .

“Yeah, well, it got us through the Upside Down, didn’t it?”

Before Eddie can respond with something snippy, Steve stumbles into the kitchen. His hair’s a wreck, and Eddie desperately just wants to pull on it.

“What are you wearing?” Robin asks. Steve doesn’t say anything. Instead, he takes one of the slushies and heads out the door. The slam of aluminum on aluminum shakes the room.

Everything silent, except for the quiet sound of “Running up that Hill” on Max’s walkman. Robin locks eyes with Eddie, and a silent understanding passes between them. She frowns.

Nancy moves to follow him, but Robin stops her. “I got this,” She promises, and Eddie trusts that she does. She soundlessly slips out the door after Steve.

Steve Harrington is sitting on the steps alone when it finally hits him, why he's sitting out on the steps alone. There’s more vodka in his slushie, the slushie Eddie made for him , and he gulps it down. Because Steve is scared. And he’s scared of the fact that he’s scared. And he’s scared that fear and guilt is exactly what the brain-melting monster that is coming for all of them feeds off of.

Maybe his dad was right: he really should’ve gotten his ass out of Hawkins for college. But there’s part of Steve that wonders if he can ever truly leave Hawkins behind; if the red dust in the dirt will always be stuck to his sweat when the temperature rises above 80 wherever he goes; if the mysteries and the nail-studded baseball bats and the boys in the trailer park will haunt him his whole life long.

The door to the trailer swings open, nearly hitting Steve. Another part of Hawkins he could never leave tramps out onto the steps with him.

“Hey, drama queen,” Robin says, dropping down next to him. “You gonna talk about the show you put on in there, or should I just keep making jokes about how ridiculous your outfit is?”

Steve just presses his forehead into her shoulder. He doesn’t even realize he’s crying until the tears press into his skin, and soak through the thin fabric of her thrift store jacket. Robin instinctively wraps her arm around him, pulling him into her. She presses her lips to his hair, and even now, Steve wishes it could’ve been her.

How easy would’ve been to make a life with his best friend? His better half? The only person he knows who manages to keep him enthralled in talks about movies and music and marching band drama? But they’d never quite clicked romantically even before he knew about her, and Robin coming out entirely cemented it. She was his soulmate, but not in that bullshit Nora Ephron way. And all this time, he was convinced it was because of her, because she just wasn’t made that way. 

Now, he’s having a lot of fantasies about a pair of shitty toy handcuffs and wondering if maybe it’d been his fault all along.

“Talk to me, Stevo,” Robin whispers. He laughs just a bit, mostly just exhaling air onto her shoulder and smiling into it. But it fades quickly. And then the tears come back.

“Rob, I…” He takes a breath, and then he says it. “I’m scared.”

And Steve sends out a prayer to every God he knows, hoping that Robin loves him the way he loves her. Hoping that that’s all it takes to clue her in. Hoping that, after a year, he doesn’t have to say anything else. Because he can’t. Because he doesn’t even know where to begin.

Her hand squeezes his shoulder. “I had Ms. Castler for homeroom in fifth grade,” She whispers, “And she sat me next to Liz Fender one day. Oh, god, I thought I was going to combust. I just… I wanted so desperately to be friends with her. I wanted to braid her curly brown hair, and talk to her about the Star Wars pin she always wore, and be in her friend group of cool nerdy girls. And so I did it. I forced my way into her friend group day by day, homeroom class by homeroom class.” She takes a sip of Steve’s drink, and coughs. “Gross.” He takes it out of her hand, and takes a sip, forehead still glued to her shoulder. She runs a soft hand through his hair.

“Anyway, she invited me over to her house, one night, for this big sleepover she was having. And I was so nervous. Not because I wasn’t friends with these girls or anything, but because they were the kind of girls who got Baby-Alives and Easy Bake Ovens for Christmas and always had new shoes on the first day of school. Way outside of my tax bracket.

“But then we were sitting in the basement, the six of us, and Dana Cole asked everyone if they thought Tommy H was cute.” Steve finally breaks away from Robin, the look on his face one of understanding and a little bit of disgust. “Yeah, yeah. I know, Tommy fuckin’ H. But I didn’t even know we were supposed to like boys yet,” She says, her voice suddenly cracking. “And everyone went around talking about who they liked and why and… And I realized I liked Liz. Like actually liked Liz. I didn’t even know that was a possibility until that moment.”

Steve brushes his face with the back of his hand, and then pushes off the steps. He’s pacing, now, his hand folded behind his head. His sides scream, but it helps to numb his brain just a bit, like the vodka. “I don’t know what’s happening, Robin.”

In one swoop, she’s off the patio, and blocking his path. “Look at me.” Steve’s hands drop to his side, and she takes them slowly. “Tell me about what you’re feeling.”

“I can’t.”

“Remember how I thought you would hate me if you knew the truth? I was wrong, then. And you’re wrong now. You can talk to me .”

Steve sighs, and his shoulders sag. He doesn’t recognize his words as he speaks them, but they flow out of him like they’ve been there forever. “While you guys were gone, Eddie fixed me up. And we talked. And I just kept thinking about how nice it would be to press into him and disappear for a while.” The fear in his voice breaks for just a moment with the joy that accompanies his thought. “I’m so tired, Rob. And confused. I just… want to go back to that moment, in his bed, and never have to leave it.”

“Steve… You like Eddie, don’t you?”

And now the tears are back, and Steve is shaking his head. His grip tightens on Robin, like he’s so scared she’ll float away. He bites his lip, hard, and looks at the ground. “I can’t. I can’t.”

“Hey–”

“Robin, I can’t .” Suddenly, he lets go of Robin’s hands, and the dam breaks. Every thought Steve has had in the last hour – or maybe it’s been days, weeks, whole lifetimes – comes pouring out. “I loved Nancy. I know I loved Nancy . And I loved you, so much that for about a month the words just friends made my chest hurt . And I have kissed almost every girl who I went to high school with, and I had sex with maybe half of them–”

“Gross.”

“--And I have paused Fast Times at 53 minutes and 5 seconds ! So how come I can’t get the thought of Eddie fucking Munson’s hands and his hair and his smile and his fucking dead mom out of my brain no matter how fucking hard I try? I can’t be… I can’t be this .” His hands are in his hair, and he rips through it, making a mess of it. Everything feels hot and tight and terrifying.

Robin rests a hand on his chest. “Steve. It’s scary as hell. I know. I mean, look at me. I’m falling hard for a girl and I don’t think I can ever tell her how I feel because I can’t risk it.”

“Vickie likes boobies,” Steve mumbles, despite himself. Robin grimaces.

“Right. Yeah. Vickie. That’s who I…” She taps her fist on his chest, and looks away. “It hurts, a lot of the time. And it’s fucking hard. But there’s also a big beautiful world out there where you and Eddie can be happy and normal and stay in that bed all day with no one bothering you.”

Steve shakes his head. “Robin, I like girls. I have always liked girls. I’m not gay. I don’t… I can’t like guys.” His face is white, and strained, and he looks like he’s trying not to cry again.

But Robin’s just smiling at him, with the smile Robin reserves only for Steve.

“Steve Harrington, is this sexuality crisis because you don’t think you are capable of liking girls and guys?”

He shrinks, just a bit. Just like Robin knows Steve does when people uncomplicate the things he makes so complicated for himself. “I mean… Part of it, yeah.” Because not all of it is, but he doesn’t know how to quantify the part of it that isn’t . He doesn’t know how to explain that his heart starts beating all too fast when Eddie smiles both because Eddie has the perfect smile and because Eddie shouldn’t have the perfect smile. But Robin knows Steve, and Steve knows Robin knows Steve, and so Steve knows Robin knows what he means by part of it .

“Bisexuality exists,” Robin says. It’s the explanation Steve needs, but doesn’t entirely understand. He blinks, and her smile grows a bit wider. Because Steve also knows Robin loves explaining things she’s passionate about. “Plenty of people like guys and girls alike,” Robin continues. “You can do that, ya know.”

“You… what?”

“I did not spend a three months listening to David Bowie every time we drove to work for you to not know about bisexuality.”

“David Bowie likes guys?”

“Jesus!” Robin presses the palm of hand to her face, but she’s laughing. Soon, Steve is too.

“I am nothing like David Bowie,” Steve says, and then Robin’s laughing even harder.

“Yeah, because David Bowie can sing!”

“Wait, no one ever said that .”

“Steve.”

“I can sing!”

“And so can Tammy Thompson!”

“No, okay, that is just offensive. Do you really think I can’t sing?”

“You’ve driven me to work and school since August. I know you can’t sing. ”

Steve opens his mouth to protest, and then closes his mouth. He grins. “I-“ Steve begins, standing up to her challenge, “I will be king.”

“No, no, no!” Robin shrieks, and covers her face with her hands.

“And you, you will be queen.” Steve gives her a little mock bow, and offers her a hand. Despite herself, and Steve’s god awful singing, she takes it. He spins her around. “Though nothing will drive them away-”

In the distance, a hospital door slams, and Hopper comes back into the hallway. He’s smiling lightly. Eddie notices the patchy buzzcut he has, which is ever apparent under the fluorescents. Smiling at me , Eddie realizes. There’re no nurses or doctors around right now, so Eddie smirks up at her and says, “Either someone has a crush on me, or Nancy Wheeler has put two and two together.”

Steve moans quietly in the bed, his eyes still glued shut. Eddie smiles at him, and watches him from a distance. She slips out the door and, with a quick glance at Steve, Robin scampers after her. Eddie watches them go, then turns his attention to the hospital bed. The room is impossibly too hot to cuddle with Steve, so Eddie just moves to awkwardly hover at his side. He runs a hand through Steve’s sweat-drenched hair, and watches the IV slowly drip into Steve’s arm. Eddie hates hospitals, and has since his mom passed. Every visit reminds him of her last days, and the few times he saw her fail to help the kids she knew.

Steve’s chart pokes straight up by his bed, and Eddie squints to read it. There’s two infections noted on there, and Eddie frowns just a bit. “I shouldn’t have tried to get you drunk,” Eddie mumbles.

“You were trying?” Steve whispers. Eddie legitimately jumps.

“Fuck, Stevie!”

Steve cracks a small, wounded smile. “Stevie?”

“Shut up.”

“It’s hot as fuck in here.”

Eddie shrugs. “Yeah, well, you literally had to sweat the devil out. And I think you’re already running a fever–”

“Because you got me drunk?”

Eddie just wants to punch him and tell him no, you just fucking suck at caring for infections . Instead, he leans down and gives Steve a quick kiss. “Yeah, Stevie. Because I got you drunk.” And then the air conditioning kicks on.

Steve spends the next day in and out of consciousness, and Eddie never leaves his side. His body still feels weird, and it can easily be written off as the antibiotic drip making him woozy. But part of him knows it’s his brain is readjusting to the amount of real-estate it can take up in Steve’s body. Every stolen touch from Eddie helps – everywhere his hands roam when no one’s looking makes Steve want every inch of his skin back for himself.

His physical healing is uncannily quick, and the hospital offers to discharge him once he spends more time awake than he does asleep. The cops offer to drop Eddie’s charges, too—Hopper’s reinstatement takes only as long as it does for Joyce to find the rules on special elections for sheriff at the library. Steve thinks they’ve pumped too much morphine into his body when he first sees Jim, but everyone gets him up to speed.

And then he ends the night again in Eddie Munson’s bed, while they prepare for the impending battle. Steve sleeps a lot, lulled by the rustle of his friends breezing through the trailer every once in a while. His arms ache for Eddie’s figure, but only Nancy and Robin know about them. He isn’t quite prepared for this secret to get out there just yet.

Finally, the next morning, Robin wakes him up softly before the sun comes up. “How you feeling, cowboy?”

“Cowboy?”

“Ya know, because you’re into leather now?” Steve punches her arm. She grins. “Attaboy. You think you’re down for the fight today?”

“I think I need to get dressed.” Steve doesn’t get dressed. He doesn’t move. Instead, he wakes up hours later to Dustin at the end of his bed—Eddie’s bed. Dustin’s hair and clothes are a mess of dirt and blood and torn armor, and when he finally speaks, Steve thinks he might still be dreaming.

“We lost.”

“What?”

“Me and Eddie. We lost.”

“Where is he?”

And its Dustin’s words now that leave Steve in a freefall, send him spinning headfirst into the little time the last few days provided. “He stopped running.”

Because they both know what he means. Because otherwise Eddie would be there himself. Because the world is still cold and cruel and set up to ruin everything Steve could ever try to build for himself.

He doesn’t move for another day. Robin has to force food down his throat, and even then, he can tell she wants to curl into herself and give up, too. There’re tears cried until there aren’t tears left to cry, and water chugged so that there’re more tears to cry. Mike asks Steve how he and Eddie knew each other, and Steve thinks his chest might just cave in.

“Vecna got away,” Steve says suddenly. Robin’’s curled into his side, and she startles when he speaks. Looking back on it, he isn’t sure he’s done that in a day. “Eddie’s fucking gone, and Vecna’s still fucking out there, and we couldn’t do anything.”

Robin pulls him into her chest, and he’s sobbing again. Big huge screaming sobs that shake both of them and pull at everything Steve has left. He wants to die. He wants to swap places with Eddie. He wants to have woken up and gotten dressed and won the goddamn battle by his boyfriend’s side.

Because of course they’d be boyfriends now, wouldn’t they? Steve would pop the question just as easily as he did with Nancy and they’d live happily ever after. And Eddie would get his diploma. And they’d leave this cursed town for ever.

“Why did I apply to Scoops,” Robin whispers, as Steve starts to regain his composure. “I could’ve gone my whole life not knowing about alternate dimensions or brain suckers…”

“Or me.”

“The worst burden of them all.”

“Fuck you.”

Robin kisses his forehead, and mumbles, “I love you.”

“I know.”

“You need to stop working at Family Video.”

On the second day, Nancy joins them in Eddie’s comically small bed, curled up between Steve and Robin. It’s a bit strange at first, thinking that he’s third-wheeling with his ex-girlfriend and her new S.O., but it’s also one that he’s used to. And it doesn’t change their dynamic one bit: they all hold onto each other like there’s no hope outside of that room alone.

On the third day, Steve sees his second ghost in the last week.

He wakes up before the girls, all of them still intertwined in Eddie’s sheets. Steve can’t help but reminisce on how Freshman him would give him now a high-five. The thought alone makes him nauseous.

Slowly, Steve extracts himself from the situation, and sneaks out into the kitchen. His feet feel weird pacing on solid ground after so much time spent in the bed.

He digs through the limited supplies in the kitchen, managing to extract some coffee grounds from their groceries. He sets to work, putting together Wayne’s old Mr. Coffee and filling it up. He leans against the counter and hits start, and then his sobs once again shoot through his body.

Someone wraps their arms around his waist, and pulls him in. For a minute, Steve can’t help but think about how much they all smell like Eddie’s smoke and soap after all their days in his house. And he’s pleasantly reminded of the comfort Eddie’s arms used to offer, even if they sent him reeling at the same time.

“I’m sorry,” Steve whispers.

“It’s okay,” Eddie whispers back.

On instinct, Steve spins around and punches Eddie right in the nose. He watches Eddie stumble back, waiting for him to melt into the zombies all of his friends have struggled with in Vecna’s mind palace.

Only, he doesn’t. Instead, he just clutches his bloody, broken nose, and swears softly under his breath.

“Fucking hell, Harrington,” He mumbles. “When I said I liked it rough, I didn’t mean like that.”

Steve goes dead still. “Holy fuck. Eddie.”

“Yeah?”

“I thought you were dead.”

“I figured.” Eddie grabs a dishrag off the counter and presses it to his face. Then, he smiles at Steve. “Do you know how many bats I had to fight off to get here? This hero shit sucks man.”

Within seconds, Steve pulls him into the biggest hug Steve Harrington might be capable of. Because its Eddie and he’s okay and Steve’s just a little bit in love with him already. And he can’t stop himself from saying all these things, because this is it. Vecna hasn’t won. Eddie’s home safe and sound and in Steve’s arms again and they can always just turn up the heat if he’s hurt.

Eventually, they have to wake Robin and Nancy. They have to call the rest of the party. About Eddie and Steve and Hopper surviving it all that makes it so much more manageable in everyone’s eyes.

It also means, though, that everyone must get ready. Spring break’s coming to a close. The kids – Everyone but Steve – have classes to prepare for and chores to do. And after a light celebration, everyone has to go home and face the right-side-up world.

“Do you wanna stay?” Eddie asks Steve. He stands at the front door, watching everyone leave. Steve wonders if he’ll ever tell any of them about him and Eddie. He hopes they last long enough that he can.

“Yeah.” He loops an arm around Eddie’s waist, and he’s impossibly smitten with how well they fit together. He’s impossibly smitten with Eddie, too, and maybe that’s why he loves this so much.

“Did you mean it, earlier?”

Steve looks over at Eddie, but for all the studying he’s done of the boy, he can’t make out his expression. “Mean what?”

“You said you were a little bit in love with me.”

“Oh.” Of course that’s what he meant. Because Steve fucked up. Because Steve moved too fast. Because Eddie wasn’t in love with Steve and now it’s going to ruin everything. “I mean, I don’t, like, wanna push you or anything, it was just a comment and you were alive and—”

“Steve, it’s okay!” Eddie glances over at Steve, and, for a brief moment, Steve feels somehow as if he’s looking in a mirror. The logical side of his brain wins over and tells him he most definitely isn’t. Then, Eddie nuzzles his face into Steve’s neck. “I fought killer bats to get to you,” He whispers.

“Yeah?”

“Because I am ridiculously, stupidly, in love with you.”

“I love you too, prison boy.” Eddie laughs against Steve’s skin, and Steve instantly knows how much he means it.
